 This refusal to cooperate on Putins/Russias part is considered to be a coordinated effort to avoid the full extent of the murder plot being made public. Russia is once again covering their collective butts in the face of what could turn into International condemnation if its proven that they sent Agents into a Foreign Country to assassinate someone. I wouldn't be surprised if the object of England's extradition requests, ie, the murder suspect, doesn't show up dead in Russia himself in order to put this whole issue to rest. After all, no defendant, no trial, no political or International exposure or embarrassment. It's as simple as that.

Are eastern european states just banana republics where law and justice is awarded to the highest bidder or the one with best links to the incumbent regime?
 

 There's a lot more to this Russian gambit than a mere refusal to co-operate with British requests for extradition of the suspect in the Litvinenko affair.
 
 Russia is turning dangerous (from the Western perspective) on a number of issues that include the American plan to build missile sites in Eastern Europe, and the moral support that the Ukraine gets from the West in its struggle to become a democracy. 
 
 Putin is using the fact that Russia has vast reserves of oil and gas - on which some European countries are already becoming dependent - to finance the restoration of Russian military might, and to recover international prestige after the chaos of the Yeltsin years. 
 
 James.

 The russian government has not extradited their citizens since the soviet union fell. Surely the british were aware of this.

He has crapped all over the US constitution for years and treated it with complete contempt. For him to fall back on "I can't, it is unconstitutional" from "Just a ######n piece of paper" would be questionable. As far as I know, Putin has a pretty good record on such things. Expecting him to trash his countries contitution in order to make the british happy is unreasonable.

Maybe somebdy could explain the outrage here. The british made and extradition request. Extradition of a russian citizen is unconstitutional, so the russian government refused.

 
 The outrage is that Russia (alledgedly) sent an agent into Britain to murder a British citizen and in the process exposed a whole bunch of other British citizens to a deadly radioactive isotope. The UK government has no choice but to request extradition whether they know it will be denied or not. The alternatives are to do nothing or to risk an escalation by assassinating Lugovoi in a tit-for-tat style.
 
 Now we get to say that we made a reasonable request and Russia refused to cooperate. Not to mention that - whilst I know little of Russia's constitution - I find it hard to believe that Putin is adhering to it much with some of the persecution of various oligarchs going on over there at the moment.

 Or how about the 4 Russian diplomats that have been expelled from the UK for no other reason than being the target of British political retaliation. Where's the moral outrage on that one, eh?
 
 I find this smug attitude of Western superiority to be quite disgusting.
 
 I think some of you need to pull your heads out of your asses and realize that the West doesn't own the world (anymore).

 Persecution on political grounds? We are talking about a kingpin of russian organized crime here. He has been indicted in russia for fraud and political corruption (bribing politicians) and there is absolutly no question that he is guilty as sin. Now he is hiding in Britain and actively planning a violent coup in order to overthrow the elected government...and he lays all this out to a british newspaper. 
 
 Political persecution if he returns? Probably not. Execution for treason? That one seems more likely. 
 
 In the extradition rhetoric arena, the russians are looking a LOT more reasonable then the british.

 The British refusal to return Boris Berezovsky to Russia, is because he has been granted refugee status on the grounds that he has good reasons to fear persecution on political grounds in his home state.

 He called for the violent overthrow of a democratically elected Government. I would guess if he didn't have so much money he would have been kicked out Country long ago. We also refuse to extradite Akhmed Zakayev who has been accused of being a Chechen terrorist.
 
 To Russia it seems they must change their constitution to suit us where as we would never do such a thing. Would the UK Government hand over a UK citizen in these circumstances?
Count Otto

He called for the violent overthrow of a democratically elected Government.

 
 No he didn't. He said he'd finance opposition to Putin's government. To quote him: "I do support direct action, I do not advocate or support violence," and he specifically referenced the bloodless revolutions of Georgia and Ukraine. This is well in line with his liberal stance on politics and economics during and after Yeltsin. He's no hard-liner. 
 
 I should imagine there would be some shady dealings involved in his rise to prosperity - the same could be said of most (if not all) of Russia's oligarchs but Putin's not after him for that. He's after him because he's strong opposition. *That* is why we've not extradited him.
 
 If he didn't have so much money Putin wouldn't even be after him.
 
 
We also refuse to extradite Akhmed Zakayev who has been accused of being a Chechen terrorist.

 
 Zakayev is more of a freedom fighter than Che Guevara ever was. He was arrested in Denmark - they said the Russian charges were not backed by evidence; he went to Germany - they didn't even bother to arrest him; he came to the UK - we arrested him and then decided he was a political dissident and would face torture and probably death if returned to Russia. The fact that the EU can agree on this should say it all.
daewoo

No he didn't. He said he'd finance opposition to Putin's government. To quote him: "I do support direct action, I do not advocate or support violence," and he specifically referenced the bloodless revolutions of Georgia and Ukraine. This is well in line with his liberal stance on politics and economics during and after Yeltsin. He's no hard-liner. 

 
 http://www.guardian.co.uk/russia/article/0,,2056321,00.html
 
 
The Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky has told the Guardian he is plotting the violent overthrow of President Putin from his base in Britain after forging close contacts with members of Russia's ruling elite.
 In comments which appear calculated to enrage the Kremlin, and which will further inflame relations between London and Moscow, the multimillionaire claimed he was already bankrolling people close to the president who are conspiring to mount a palace coup.

 
 
"We need to use force to change this regime," he said. "It isn't possible to change this regime through democratic means. There can be no change without force, pressure." Asked if he was effectively fomenting a revolution, he said: "You are absolutely correct."

 You might want to try to stay current on these things.
 
 
I should imagine there would be some shady dealings involved in his rise to prosperity - the same could be said of most (if not all) of Russia's oligarchs but Putin's not after him for that. He's after him because he's strong opposition. *That* is why we've not extradited him.
 
 If he didn't have so much money Putin wouldn't even be after him.

 
 That may be....or, it could be that they are after him because he is, and has always been, a major player in the russian mob.
 
 http://www.forbes.com/free_forbes/1996/1230/5815090a.html
 
 
Power. Politics. Murder. Boris Berezovsky could teach the guys in Sicily a thing or two.

 
 
The host of the lavish affair? A wealthy Russian car dealer named Boris Berezovsky. 
 
 Ronald Lauder probably did not know that his host is a powerful gangland boss and the prime suspect in Russia's most famous murder investigation. Explains Lauder: "The invitations went out in President Yeltsin's name." 

 
 Youa re welcome to read the article....7 pages of his mis deeds, and they barely touch the tip of the iceburg.
 
 The british have often had problems with the concept of cause and effect. your buddy Boris is anti Putin because Putin has the reputation in russia essentially as a gnagbuster. The russian ogliarchs that he is going after that you seem to be so concerned with are organized crime figures. The russian people elected putin because he was clean....no ties to organized crime...and because he promised to bring the russian mafia to its knees. Now he is following up on those promises. 
 
 The British dislike Putin because he refuses to allow Russia to be treated like a vanquished enemy. Now they are in the unenviable position of backing the russian mafia against the democratically elected government. IMO it has to be one of the absolute stupidest things that the brits have ever done. Do they REALLY THINK that if they help the russian mob, which the population disaproves of totally, take over the government they are going to haev any kind of decent relationship with them? You would think that they would have learned by now that if you help put tyrants in control of a country, the people tend to hate you.
Winston Smith

Putin and his KGB are worst than the Russian mafia, for they are infinitely more powerful and harmful.
 There is no political oposition in Russia for there is no free press. Putin is turning back the clock towards opression, nothing new in Russia which has almost always been a country run by czars, and dictators. Putin has had murdered or imprisoned anybody who dares to criticise him or even worse oppose him
Count Otto

[url]You might want to try to stay current on these things.

 
 The quote I provided you was in response to the fact that Berezovsky realised that he'd been taken out of context in that Grauniad article. It's quite staggering that such a left-wing paper now seems to be in bed with the right wing...
 
 
That may be....or, it could be that they are after him because he is, and has always been, a major player in the russian mob.

 
 The first Forbes article claiming that resulted in the magazine being taken to court, by Berezovsky, for libel. It was settled in his favour out of court. The trouble is, he was being extorted by the mob for some time (as was every other rich businessman in Russia) so I imagine he did make connections.
 
 Several attempts were made on his life. At one point his chauffeur was decapitated when his car was destroyed...
 
 
The British dislike Putin because he refuses to allow Russia to be treated like a vanquished enemy. Now they are in the unenviable position of backing the russian mafia against the democratically elected government. IMO it has to be one of the absolute stupidest things that the brits have ever done. You would think that they would have learned by now that if you help put tyrants in control of a country, the people tend to hate you.

 
 ...all of which we could argue over back and forth all day except the reason we aren't handing either of these boys over is because they face the very real prospect of death or torture on their return. If you wanted evidence of this, what better timing? I wake up this morning and MI5 are stating that they prevented another Russian-sponsored attempt on Berezovsky's life on British soil.
 
 Now I'm sorry, but if Russia popped over to your country and started offing your citizens at will, I don't think you'd be offering the moral high ground to them. It boggles the mind!
 
 Incidentally we can discuss Putin's "gang-busting" exploits if you like. Like prosecuting Mikhail Khodorkovsky in exactly the same way he's gone after Berezovsky. Smearing him as a gangster. He was another who was funding opposition to Putin.
 
 We can also discuss Putin's own skeletons. http://www.afpc.org/rrm/rrm755.htm
 
 "Putin "presents himself as a relentless opponent of corruption," the Times of London reports, but "documents dating back to his time as a bureaucrat in St. Petersburg reveal a man who appeared less eager to enforce the law during the chaotic and crime-ridden days that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union." An eight-year-old investigation by the St. Petersburg city council found the city had been cheated of millions of dollars in revenue, and recommended at the time that Putin be dismissed." 
 
 Putin's administration is rottent to the core, suppressing free speech, murdering journalists who don't tow the party line, arresting his opponents on trumped up charges. I'm proud that my country won't send people back into the wolf den.

 I started this to see if I could engage some of the bots in more than a one post wonder, but this much more entertaining. emoticon_xgood
 
 Couple of points; 
 The expelled diplomats specifically have not been accused of spying.
 I'm not entirely sure how diplomats positions relate to the specific case of the murder, but no one accused the British government of clarity and/or logic.
 
 When a Brit gets accused of espionage the standard HMG position is to "Neither confirm or deny" the charge. We do extradite murder suspects and those suspected of fraud, eg. the 4 Bankers extradited to the US.
James

He called for the violent overthrow of a democratically elected Government. I would guess if he didn't have so much money he would have been kicked out Country long ago. We also refuse to extradite Akhmed Zakayev who has been accused of being a Chechen terrorist.
 
 To Russia it seems they must change their constitution to suit us where as we would never do such a thing. Would the UK Government hand over a UK citizen in these circumstances?

 Berezovsky was a member of the "oligarchy" who plundered the Russian state economy when it was extensively privatised during Yeltsin's chaotic regime.
 
 After assisting in the transition of Putin (into power), he fled to Britain with his booty and he was granted political asylum here. Under British law he cannot be extradited to Russia because he has acquired refugee status, and he has convinced the courts that he has a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of his political opinions. However, the Russian government also claims that he is a fugitive from justice on account of his fraudulent acquisition of state assets. 
 
 Asylum law in the UK is based upon the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and its subsequent amendments. This law will not be repudiated in order to mollify President Putin.
 
 I believe I've described the situation objectively.
 
 James.

 "The service oversees every visa application from a potential intelligence officer coming to Britain - and tries to keep out the more experienced ones. 
 
 Those that do get in usually operate from the Russian embassy in Kensington. Here they report to a controller, known as "the resident".

 The rivalry and antipathy of the Cold War probably won't return, but Britain and America seem to be heading into a Cool War with Russia.

Alicia Andrews

Hello! My name is Alicia. You know I hate it when people start to roll a turd especially if there is actually no reason to do so 
 Let's take for example the latest event that involves British Council in Russia and the order to close officers in two Russian cities. Let's put aside all the hysteria that Western media has stirred up about that happening and take a practical view of the situation. Is anyone here aware about the real reason why the two council offices got closed down? Many news media sources such as The Telegraph or The New York Times insist that it was due to some political motivation, etc. But that's ######## and chief editors of these newspapers and other news media know it! They lie to their audience because they are paid for turning the world against Russia. 
 So, what happened to British Council in Russia in sober fact? Firstly, this organization was not properly registered to work on the territory of Russia. Secondly, BC evades taxes. Lastly, this organization is known to be sponsoring various NGOs and youth organizations (various extremist movements among them) that work against current political system of Russia and strive for change of power. Do I need to say that that's illegal in every other country so why making Russia an exception? 
 As this takes place, an incident with the organization's director Stephen Kinnock comes to the front. He was stopped by Russian police officers for driving offence a day before closing British Council offices. After Stephen Kinnock was stopped, it turned out that he was drunken and there were two hookers sitting on the rear seat! According to Russian laws, drunken driving leads to detention but Stephen Kinnock was not arrested after all because he has got legal protection as an accredited diplomat. So that's what he was doing instead of dealing with problems of British Council in Russia! 
 That's nice, isn't it? So after all that I begin to think that the whole fuzzbuzz about the closing in American and British media was merely an attempt to frame up Russia itself and allow Stephen Kinnock get away with it!

post_info.post_title: Was there really any political motivation for closing British Council in Russia
